meta-model.fullname: CMCC Complete Sociology and Anthropology ToE Meta-Model
meta-model.name: Sociology & Anthropology ToE Meta-Model
meta-model.description: A unified meta-model capturing social structures, cultural norms, and interaction networks. This model encodes survey data, demographic records, and social network relationships, and enables predictive modeling of social behavior and network dynamics.

meta.title: CMCC Complete Sociology & Anthropology ToE Meta-Model
meta.subtitle: A Declarative Framework for Modeling Social Dynamics and Cultural Norms
meta.abstract: This meta-model represents social structures, cultural norms, and interaction networks in a syntax‐free, ACID‐compliant environment. By leveraging declarative primitives, it supports community health indexing, social cohesion metrics, and predictive modeling of network dynamics.

entities.name: Community
entities.description: Represents a social community or group with shared cultural or demographic characteristics.

fields.name: demographics
fields.description: Key demographic information about the community.

lookups.name: interactions
lookups.description: Social interactions recorded within the community.

aggregations.name: community_health_index
aggregations.description: Aggregate measure of the community's overall well-being.

aggregations.name: social_cohesion_metric
aggregations.description: Quantifies the degree of cohesion within the community.

aggregations.name: cross_community_interaction_score
aggregations.description: Evaluates the frequency and intensity of interactions between this community and other communities.

aggregations.name: cohesion_between_communities
aggregations.description: Measures synergy or collaborative engagement between this community and neighboring communities.

aggregations.name: community_leadership_index
aggregations.description: Assesses the presence and impact of recognized leaders within the community.

aggregations.name: generational_shift_index
aggregations.description: Tracks how the age distribution changes over time within the community.

calculated_fields.name: predictive_behavior_model
calculated_fields.description: Model predicting future social behavior trends based on current data.

entities.name: Individual
entities.description: Represents a person within a community.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description: Reference to the community the individual belongs to.

lookups.name: cultural_norms
lookups.description: Cultural norms that the individual adheres to.

aggregations.name: social_influence_score
aggregations.description: Quantitative measure of the individual's influence in the network.

aggregations.name: inter_community_mobility
aggregations.description: Quantifies how many times the individual has changed community affiliation.

aggregations.name: network_brokerage_score
aggregations.description: Measures the individual's role as a bridge or broker in the social network.

aggregations.name: individual_cultural_alignment_score
aggregations.description: Assesses the individual's level of alignment with prevailing cultural norms.

calculated_fields.name: network_dynamics
calculated_fields.description: Evaluates the dynamics of the individual's social network.

calculated_fields.name: life_stage_classification
calculated_fields.description: Categorizes the individual's life stage based on age (e.g. youth, adult, senior).

entities.name: Survey
entities.description: Represents a survey conducted within a community.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description: Reference to the community where the survey was conducted.

fields.name: survey_date
fields.description: Date when the survey was administered.

lookups.name: participants
lookups.description: Individuals who participated in the survey.

aggregations.name: average_response
aggregations.description: Average response score from the survey.

aggregations.name: trend_analysis
aggregations.description: Trend analysis based on survey responses.

aggregations.name: survey_response_over_time
aggregations.description: Tracks how response patterns evolve across successive survey administrations.

aggregations.name: survey_participant_diversity_index
aggregations.description: Measures the demographic diversity of survey participants.

calculated_fields.name: predictive_model
calculated_fields.description: Predicts future social trends based on survey data.

entities.name: CulturalNorm
entities.description: Represents a cultural norm or standard within a community.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the cultural norm.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description: Reference to the community to which the norm applies.

aggregations.name: norm_adherence_index
aggregations.description: Measures the degree to which community members adhere to the norm.

aggregations.name: norm_influence_spread
aggregations.description: Calculates the rate at which this norm is adopted across individuals and communities.

aggregations.name: cultural_norm_convergence
aggregations.description: Assesses how this norm overlaps or converges with other norms within or across communities.

aggregations.name: cross_norm_interaction_effects
aggregations.description: Evaluates synergistic or conflicting effects between this norm and other norms in the community.

entities.name: SocialInteraction
entities.description: Represents an interaction between two individuals.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description: Reference to the community where the interaction took place.

fields.name: interaction_type
fields.description: Type or category of the interaction.

aggregations.name: interaction_frequency
aggregations.description: Frequency count of this type of interaction.

aggregations.name: most_active_interaction_type
aggregations.description: Identifies the most commonly occurring interaction type within this social interaction set.

aggregations.name: interaction_time_series_trend
aggregations.description: Examines how interaction frequency and types change over chronological intervals.

calculated_fields.name: dynamic_strength
calculated_fields.description: Evaluates the strength of the relationship based on interaction type and frequency.

entities.name: Family
entities.description: Represents a family unit within or across communities, capturing immediate or extended kinship ties.

fields.name: family_name
fields.description: Name of the family or the primary surname associated with it.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description: Reference to the primary community this family is associated with.

fields.name: family_structure
fields.description: JSON describing the internal structure (e.g., nuclear, extended) and notable relationships.

lookups.name: members
lookups.description: All individuals belonging to this family.

aggregations.name: family_cohesion_metric
aggregations.description: Quantifies how cohesive and interdependent the family unit is.

aggregations.name: family_size_trend
aggregations.description: Analyzes how family membership size evolves over time.

aggregations.name: family_intergenerational_support_score
aggregations.description: Measures the level of support exchanged across multiple generations within the family.

aggregations.name: predictive_family_expansion
aggregations.description: Forecasts the likelihood of new members joining or existing members leaving the family unit.

calculated_fields.name: family_lifecycle_stage
calculated_fields.description: Identifies whether the family is in an early, expanding, or mature lifecycle stage based on membership and structure.

entities.name: Organization
entities.description: Represents a formal organization, institution, or collective operating within or across communities.

fields.name: organization_type
fields.description: Type of organization (e.g., nonprofit, business, government).

fields.name: description
fields.description: High-level overview of the organization’s purpose or function.

lookups.name: associated_communities
lookups.description: Communities in which this organization operates or has membership.

aggregations.name: organizational_influence
aggregations.description: Assesses how influential the organization is based on its size and reach.

aggregations.name: org_cross_community_overlap
aggregations.description: Indicates the extent to which the organization spans multiple communities.

aggregations.name: event_sponsorship_impact
aggregations.description: Evaluates the organization's influence or visibility gained through sponsoring social events.

aggregations.name: organization_collaboration_density
aggregations.description: Measures the depth and breadth of collaborations or partnerships with other organizations.

calculated_fields.name: organizational_growth_forecast
calculated_fields.description: Predicts the organization’s potential growth or decline in membership and impact.

entities.name: SocialEvent
entities.description: Represents a significant event (e.g., gathering, protest, celebration) that occurs within or across communities.

fields.name: event_name
fields.description: Name or title of the event.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description: Primary community where the event is based.

fields.name: location
fields.description: Location or venue where the event takes place.

fields.name: details
fields.description: Additional structured data describing the event (agenda, expected turnout, organizers, etc.).

lookups.name: attendees
lookups.description: Individuals who attend or participate in the event.

aggregations.name: event_participation_level
aggregations.description: Number of attendees or participants in the event.

aggregations.name: social_event_recurrence_prediction
aggregations.description: Estimates the probability that a similar event will occur in the future based on historical patterns.

aggregations.name: event_community_engagement_index
aggregations.description: Quantifies the level of engagement and participation from the community in this event.

calculated_fields.name: social_impact_assessment
calculated_fields.description: Evaluates the social implications of the event for the community (and potentially beyond).

CulturalNorm.description: High value placed on mutual aid and support.

Organization.description: A local volunteer-run organization dedicated to community services.

root-meta-model.title: The Conceptual Model Completeness Conjecture (CMCC)
root-meta-model.subtitle: A Universal Declarative Computational Framework
root-meta-model.abstract: The Conceptual Model Completeness Conjecture (CMCC) posits that the declarative semantics of any conceptual model can be captured using five fundamental primitives—Schema (S), Data (D), Lookups (L), Aggregations (A), and Lambda Calculated Fields (F)—within an Snapshot-Consistent environment. Demonstrating Turing-completeness and aligning with Wolfram’s multiway systems, CMCC provides a universal substrate for modeling domains ranging from physics and biology to business rules and beyond. This paper formalizes CMCC’s theoretical foundations, presents diverse cross-domain examples, and outlines future directions for building a unified computational framework.

key_points: CMCC proposes that five primitives (S, D, L, A, F) suffice to model all computable domain rules.
It achieves Turing-completeness by mapping to Lambda Calculus and Rule 110.
Aligns structurally with Wolfram’s multiway systems (the Ruliad).
Demonstrates broad applicability in Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Math, etc.
A purely declarative approach: 'what' is separate from 'how' (the runtime).
implications: Potential unification of domain modeling under a single declarative rulebook.
Scalable approach to cross-domain data management and knowledge representation.
Opens possibilities for AI, simulation, and multiway branching analyses.

sections.title: Executive Summary
content: In many domains, describing “what” we want—a mathematical theorem, a business rule, a policy—involves flattening concepts into the syntax of English or code. While convenient for initial discussion, this syntax-locked approach forces us to repeatedly translate ideas between human language and machine processes. As complexity grows, these translations invite drift, ambiguity, and inefficiency.

sections.title: Starting with an English Theorem
content: Consider a simple example: the rules that define a “triangle.” In English, we might say:
A triangle is a closed shape with exactly three edges; its internal angles sum to 180°.

This is serviceable for teaching geometry, but it’s not inherently machine-actionable. If someone doesn’t speak English—or if we want to automate checks for “triangleness”—we must rewrite these rules in each environment (programming languages, software specifications, test scripts, etc.). The overhead compounds quickly.

sections.title: Describing Triangleness in Airtable
content: In contrast, we can directly capture the rules of geometry in a structural model within a tool like Airtable (or any Snapshot-Consistent environment with fields, lookups, rollups, and formulas). Instead of restating the concept in English each time, we:
• Create tables for Edges and Shapes.
• Use Lookups to link three edges to a shape.
• Add Aggregations to sum angles or count edges.
• Define Formulas to verify that exactly three edges exist, and that the total internal angle equals 180°.

In this configuration, the entire notion of “triangleness” exists as data and relationships, not locked into a single linguistic syntax. Anyone—regardless of spoken language—can inspect or extend the model to handle right triangles, acute triangles, or more advanced geometric constructions. The system remains accessible, self-describing, and effortlessly scalable.

sections.title: From Triangleness to CMCC
content: This leads to the Complete Model of Conceptual Completeness (CMCC) theorem: it posits that any conceptual rule (including the rules for “triangleness”) can be encoded using five core primitives—(S, D, L, A, F)—in an Snapshot-Consistent datastore. In essence:
• Schema for defining categories of things,
• Lookups that link records into relationships,
• Aggregations that summarize or roll up data, and
• Formulas for declarative calculations or constraints.

The rulebook (the “what” of a concept) is stored unambiguously in these five primitives, separate from the “how” of any given runtime engine. Because it is a universal structural approach—not tied to a single programming language or specialized DSL—CMCC becomes a syntax-free mirror of the underlying concept. It applies equally to geometry, biology, legal rules, quantum theories, or inventory systems. In short, if a rule can be stated in any imperative language (or in English), it can be modeled structurally under CMCC without loss of fidelity.

sections.title: Why This Matters
content: By decoupling the “what” from specific syntax, teams eliminate the repeated translation tasks that plague large projects. Modeling “triangleness” is trivial in Airtable; modeling advanced governance or physics follows the same structural pattern. CMCC solidifies the principle that once we master a small example (like a triangle), we unlock the ability to describe any computable concept. This puts an end to the question, “But will it work for my domain?”: the moment we acknowledge that geometry itself can be captured in a purely structural format, all similarly computable rules become fair game.

In sum, we move from a short English description of a concept, to a self-describing Airtable model, culminating in the CMCC theorem that guarantees we can handle any conceptual domain the same way. This progression ensures that readers—technical or otherwise—understand why syntax-free, declarative modeling is both feasible and transformative. Once you see it work with triangles, you can’t unsee its potential everywhere else.

addressing_concerns_preemptively.what_not_how: It's just a list of statements about WHAT is true at any given moment in time.  If there are a list of 100 true statements, and you add another statement - you will either now have 101 true statements, or the inferences of 1 or more of the previous statements will conflict, pointing to a problem with the conceptual model, rather than the description.  By just listing true things about WHAT is needed, it leaves the question of HOW to make that true up to the runtime engine.
addressing_concerns_preemptively.rulebook_not_the_runtime: Like a blueprint, or sheet music, the CMCC model is just the rulebook, not the runtime engine.  The runtime engine could be an existing digital twin of some reality that is simply Fed by the CMCC.  In other words, the CMCC model can represent WHAT needs to happen at virtually any level of desired functionality - as a result it can export DSLs, RDF, OWL, Sparql, GraphQL, etc. making the CMCC model a superset of legacy, language based, syntax-locked formats.
addressing_concerns_preemptively.scaleability_performance: As just the rulebook, the implementation can be assembler code written by magical mice in the night if that's the best solution.  But whatever they produce had better pass **all** of the tests derived directly from the CMCC model itself.  As long as it does WHAT it is meant to, how it does it is up to the runtime engine.  If that digital twin involves petabytes of raw data, coming in a gb per second - that's going to be a monumental engineering task.  But whatever the solution at runtime, it just needs to do WHAT is required.
addressing_concerns_preemptively.reality_is_the_best_runtime_engine: Ultimately, for physics for example, reality is the runtime engine.  This just provides the model to understand WHAT is happening at runtime.  Using Airtable to define business rules works for all but the most extreme concepts, but all it defines is exactly WHAT needs to be done.  HOW Airtable works might as well be magic.  I have absolutely no idea HOW it works, but that doesn't really matter since that's not its role in this process.  Its role is to define a high-fidelity, hyper-dimensional model that DEFINES Truth.  On the other end of the spectrum we have Reality Itself, which might as well also be magical, at least at the quantum fringes.  Here again—our models don't describe HOW the wave collapses, but WHAT a wave collapse is.  Or WHAT a Customer is, and WHAT makes them a VIP customer—not how we compute if they are a VIP in some AWS server.  VIP customers are still going to be anyone with over $1000 of sales—that is the part that's invariant.
addressing_concerns_preemptively.bright_red_lines: Separating out WHAT is true from HOW to make it true at runtime draws a BRIGHT RED LINE about what KIND of change is being made.  Additionally, the types of changes that can be made to the model are also separated into two radically different types by another BRIGHT RED LINE.  The first type of change is one where the domain is simply being extended.  In these cases, the CI/CD pipeline will pick up those changes and they will simply be deployed to the dev/test environment.  By contrast, if the domain itself is changed, because changing the schema or rules for a domain is a fundamentally different CATEGORY of change than simply adding another widget to the tens of thousands of widgets that are already in the datastore.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Mathematics CMCC Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A structured model covering foundational mathematics, including sets, functions, proofs, structures, and category theory.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Physics ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A unified model for physics, including classical mechanics, quantum mechanics, gauge fields, wavefunctions, relativity, and black hole dynamics.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Chemistry ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: Extends the Physics TOE with atomic structures, molecular interactions, bonds, and chemical reactions.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Biology ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: Bridges Chemistry and Physics TOEs to model biological systems, including genes, proteins, metabolism, and cellular structures.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Artificial Intelligence ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: Encapsulates machine learning, neural networks, training datasets, reinforcement learning, and inference mechanisms.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Economics ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A computational model for economic agents, markets, transactions, and supply-demand constraints.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Finance ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A computational model for financial assets, corporate finance, risk management, capital structure, etc.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Mergers & Acquisitions ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A computational model for M&A deals, synergy analysis, due diligence, purchase agreements, etc.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Venture Capital ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A computational model for startup funding, term sheets, cap tables, equity splits, etc.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: DevOps ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A computational model for development operations, CI/CD pipelines, resource usage, etc.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Astronomy ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: An extension of the Physics TOE to model celestial bodies, star systems, orbital dynamics, and large-scale cosmic structures.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Geology
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A model integrating physics and chemistry to represent minerals, rock formations, and tectonic processes.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Medicine & Healthcare ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A unified model capturing foundational aspects of medicine and healthcare, including patient records, clinical trial data, treatment plans, and healthcare analytics.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Legal Systems & Compliance ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A unified model for legal systems, contracts, statutory frameworks, and regulatory compliance.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.fullname: Climate Science and Environmental Modeling ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Climate Science ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A unified model for climate science and environmental modeling, capturing climate variables, ecosystems, pollution sources, and environmental data with built-in predictive and forecast capabilities.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Cybersecurity ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A unified model for cybersecurity covering threat models, vulnerabilities, IT asset mappings, incident logs, and security audits.

CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.name: Sociology & Anthropology ToE Meta-Model
CMCC_ToEMM_Domain_List.description: A structured model capturing social structures, cultural norms, and interaction networks using survey data, demographic records, and social network relationships.
